popups.text: ## Welcome to **The Pyramid Puzzles!** üèúÔ∏è

This is a game based on **'The Chinese Room Argument'**. 

It's a philosophical thought experiment by **John Searle** that aims to see if modern computers can ever *'understand'* the things they've been programmed to do.

You're a new intern in the **Hieroglyph Translation Department** in the University of New South Wale's Egyptology department.

You've been sent to Egypt to help translate these ancient messages! You will receive a message written in Hieroglyphs from the outside, and your job is to use the **dictionary and rulebook** provided to create the right response, and send that back outside. 

Make sense?
Let me show you the ropes. Follow along with the directions I give you.

**Step 1:** You receive a message from the outside.

Look, one's just come in below! Try dragging it around.

**Step 2:** Open your **rulebook** to find out how to respond.

You can drag the popup around as needed. After the tutorial, if you want to close it, just click the book again.

**Step 3:** To make your response, click the **dictionary** below to access your available characters.

You can drag the popout dictionary around too!

**Step 4:** Using the rule stated in the rulebook, drag the characters from the dictionary onto the paper in the **right order**.

 Alternatively, you can also just click the tiles on the dictionary or paper to instantaneously transfer symbols onto or off of the paper!
**Step 5:** Great! Now both of those paper slips are ready to combine. Click on the **stapler** to activate **stapler mode**.
**Step 6:** Fantastic, now you can click the highlighted order to complete the response and submit the order!

### üéâ Tutorial Complete!

I think you're ready to do this for real.

Keep a look out on the top left to keep track of how you're progressing. Check out the rulebook popout to see all the new rules, pay attention to the bottom of it which lets you swap pages.

 We'll be explaining the meaning of all this labour soon. Good luck!

*P.S. If you ever forget how to play, you can click the help button in the top right for a quick reminder.*

Just one question for you: **Do you feel like doing this is teaching you to understand Hieroglyphs?**

Say that someone texted you using Hieroglyphs right now, with one of the rules in that rulebook, could you **intelligently respond**?

I'm going to have to disagree with you there, I'll explain why.

 And don't forget to call your new AI assistant if anything is confusing!

You are right there. But let's explore **why**.

 And don't forget to call your new AI assistant if anything is confusing!

**'Understanding'** can mean two things:

1. **Syntax:** Putting words in a correct order.
2. **Semantics:** What the words mean.

When you follow the rulebook, which type of 'understanding' are you using?

That's right! 

Your rulebook is telling you exactly how to construct an output given an input, but there's nothing there that teaches you **why** a given output should occur from those inputs. Or is there? 

*Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Hieroglyphics?*

Not quite, that would mean you understand the **meaning** behind all the characters your placing. 

But in your case you understand how to place them in the correct order, the **syntax**, but there's nothing there that teaches you 'why' you should be placing them in that order, the **semantics**. Or is there? 

*Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Hieroglyphics?*

Well that's the interesting thing. Because from the outside you would **appear to understand** Hieroglyphs. 

If you were given a rule for every possible situation, then whether someone is asking you about Geography, History, or Math, you could **always** respond. 

**But, you would never know what you're *actually* saying.** You're just following the rulebook!

buttons.text: I see, what does this all mean

popups.text:
If you hadn't realised yet, in this situation, you are the brain of a computer, the **'CPU' - Central Processing Unit**.

  ![CPU Image](/cpuDiagram.png 'CPU Diagram') 

1. You are given a **request** (input device)
2. Use your **instructions** to make your response (CPU interacting with memory)
3. Put it in the **responses pile** (output)

But I think I've done enough talking, how about I add some more rules and see if you can imagine how you might be a computer and we'll discuss more soon.

Congratulations! Another level gained. The upgrade you've unlocked this stage will be revealed soon. 

But first, how was that, do you understand Hieroglyphics any better now?

If you are confident that you can make the jump from syntax to semantics, you may be a proponent of so-called **'strong AI'**, that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve **'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence**.

But let me tell you why you should be at least a bit skeptical of that.

Right, as discussed you cannot make the jump from syntax to semantics. 

This has implications for the theory of **'strong AI'**, that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve **'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence**. Let me try and explain why this may be unlikely to be the case.

As I mentioned previously, like you right now, computers are just highly complicated **symbol manipulation machines**.

At the most basic level, they are given a series of inputs, represented as either **1** *or* **0**. Then, based on the program it's been given, it creates a new series of 1's and 0's to send back out.

At a high level, this process may be interpreted by a human observer as music, video, colour, or any number of other meaningful things. But to the computer, it's just moving around 1's and 0's, exactly the same way as you in the Hieroglyphics room, you're just moving around characters.

Do you think computer brains and human brains learn differently?

Right on, a computer's brain is different because it can never **'learn'** in the way that we think of learning. Computers are limited to understanding **syntax**. A computer never knows *why* it manipulates the symbols (1's and 0's) its given in different ways. Even if to us it seems to 'correctly' interpret our input, that's only because we told it how.

 Going into the computer's shoes, how would you know if your Egyptian dictionary turned out to be riddled with errors? You wouldn't! You cannot question your programming. 

However, I will admit, this argument is based on programs that are pre-defined. I've given you rules that provide an exact answer every time, but that's not how modern AI **LLM's - 'Large Language Models'** work.

Computers are limited to understanding **syntax**. A computer never knows *why* it manipulates the symbols (1's and 0's) its given in different ways. Humans can understand both **syntax** ***and*** **semantics**. Even if a machine seems to 'correctly' give us an answer, that's only because we told it how.

Instead of telling you, I think I'll show you. 

This is where your new upgrade kicks in. Now, for every rule you won't just be following direct programming, you're going to be **randomly generating** the response on the fly. Go check out the rule book and you'll see what I mean!

You did it! Nice job generating all those responses!

So, how was that, do you think your responses made any sense?

Precisely right, each generation was just a **random series of Hieroglyphs**.

But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.

Not exactly, all the options you generated were actually a completely **random series of characters**.

But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.

You can think of this as the initial training state for an LLM, here we are aiming to develop a **'probabilistic' model**.

AI chatbots like **ChatGPT** or **Google Gemini** start off knowing nothing. If you tried to ask it a question at this stage it would just randomly guess words. If asked ‚Äúwhat colour is a tree?‚Äù it may have responded *‚Äúballoon giant the frog‚Äù*, who knows. 

The same is the case for the letters you just made, the syntax and semantics would be completely wrong.

buttons.text: So how do we make it make sense

popups.text:
That's where **feedback** comes in. 

You can let it know when it's made a mistake, and let it try again. Then when you next generate a random response, it's like **tweaking odds on the spinwheel** to see if it gets closer or further to the answer you were expecting when asked the same question again.

And it will probably get it wrong for hundreds, even thousands of attempts. But, eventually, it will say something like *‚Äúthe colour is brown‚Äù* and the spinwheel odds will become much more biased towards that output, making it 1 in a billion that it would say something like *‚Äúballoon giant the frog‚Äù*. 

But, even once training is complete, every time an LLM answers your question it is still just continually making **good guesses** as to what the right words would be.

buttons.text: But why go through this extra effort

popups.text:
This is what allows LLM models to be **dynamic and evolving**.

If you need a human to handcraft every response to every possible question it will take quite literally forever. To a **'hard-coded'** machine the similarity between *‚Äúwhat colour is a tree?‚Äù* and *‚Äúwhat colour are trees?‚Äù* is none. They both need a separate encoding, as they use a different final character. 

Like you wouldn't know if ìÄÄìÉπìÉí and ìÄÄìÉπìÜ§ meant something similar or turned out to be have entirely different meanings. However, to an LLM, ideas can be interpreted as similar closer to how a human would do so.

That's the scary thing, **we don't know**.

They do so through **Neural Networks**, which aim to mimic the brain, but the methods that they come up with to create their answers are incomprehensible even to scientists! 

![Neural Network Image](/neuralNetwork.png 'Neural Network')

However, what we do know is that at the most fundamental level they are still dealing with the same **1's and 0's** that the computer running the hard-coded program is dealing with. For all their power, they cannot escape their hardware. 

The same as humans are constrained to their biology. You, in the Hieroglyphics Room, cannot think yourself into understanding these symbols, the same as the computer cannot ‚Äúthink‚Äù itself into understanding the meaning behind its flipping of 1's and 0's.

buttons.text: So where does that leave us

popups.text:
This leaves us with the notion that AI as we know it likely won't become **'conscious'**.

It doesn't discount the idea of new forms of intelligence forming, but just that computers as we've built them today are constrained in this way. 

But this doesn't discount the importance that emerging AI systems will have in **changing the way we live, work, and learn**. Just that, maybe, we should be careful how much we trust a system that literally doesn't know what it is talking about.
